conversation.text: Based on your preferences, I would highly recommend "The Secret" (1992). This captivating film follows a mysterious stranger who enters into and forever alters the life of a couple. He claims to be pursued by certain authorities who intend to prevent him from disclosing a secret that only he holds, whence the title. Is he lying, or insane  - or is he telling the truth? Who, if anyone, is after him? And what  *is*  - the secret? This film boasts an excellent cast including Genevieve O'Reilly, Ash Cook, James Nesbitt. The film's storyline and themes are well-crafted and offer plenty of opportunities for thought-provoking conversations. In conclusion, if you're looking for a captivating and thought-provoking film to recommend, "The Secret" (1992) is definitely worth checking out.

Based on your preference cues, I would recommend "A Tale of Two Cities" as it fits well with your preference cues.

In the novel, Valjean is a kind and compassionate man who has been falsely accused of stealing bread from a Parisian bakery. He has been held in prison for over 20 years.

The first movie is "Find Me Guilty" (2010). This is a crime drama film directed by John Herzog. The movie revolves around the lives of three young criminals in Brooklyn who become entangled with larger societal issues such as class conflict, police brutality, and drug addiction.

The second movie is "The Expendables 3" (2014). This is an action comedy film directed by Simon West. The movie revolves around a group of highly-trained mercenaries known as the "Expendables" who are brought together to undertake an impossible mission that seems beyond their abilities.

Despite being different in terms of themes, characters, and plotlines, both "Find Me Guilty" and "The Expendables 3" offer compelling and engaging stories that explore a wide range of themes such as crime, justice, law enforcement, police brutality, and drug addiction.
